body: Cause they can contain modules
@bolkedebruin, isn't that the case iff the modules do not rely on external system libraries?

If you mean that the modules in the zip require any native dependencies (.so) to be present on the host system then yes. 

If your hosts are architecturally the same then you should be able to package almost anything into the zipped dag.
We could even extend that by allowing .so in the package and use LD_PRELOAD

(So you should be able to shoot numpy around)

Another way that comes to mind (sorry typing on a phone) is to use the wheel format and let pip resolve dependencies for DAGs before we execute a task. Doing that in a virtual-Env / docker will not require root access.
Doing that in a virtualenv per task will add a bit of time to the startup of a task but will allow versioning of dependencies.
@pedrorjbr are you still working on this? if not i'd like to take it over
@bolkedebruin since you were nice enough to take a look at the original PR. I rebased and fixed the small issues I could find.
This being my first contribution to this project, let me know if I'm doing anything wrong.

Hey @zodiac . Thanks for the contrbution, but I do think you are overlooking another approach. See https://github.com/apache/incubator-airflow/pull/1603 (unfinished at the moment), which is already addressing this issue. It is your no 2, but without the downside. Furthermore, with threading (which is not real multi-threading) you get issues with "timeout" that only works on the main thread.

@bolkedebruin I took a look at #1603, it's not really the same as my option 2. AFAICT #1603 loads out of date dags on the webserver thread, which is similar to option 1 (since refresh_dags checks timestamps to only parse changed dags). It had the same drawback that if a slow-to-parse dag is added, some user request will be blocked on loading the dag.

As you are using threading (which is cooperative) and not multiprocessing the issue will remain the same for dags that are difficult to parse or am I incorrect?

The approach in #1603 indeed uses the the DB to determine if the dags need to be refreshed. This is a combination of 1 and 2 without the downside of 1 polling the filesystem for every request. Also if one of the webserver workers refreshes it will propagate to all other webserver workers, thus #1603 deals with the issue of outdated DAGs in the view (mismatch between the scheduler and webserver). 

I dont particularly like the constant polling approach that you are suggesting. This increases load on the system (atimes being updated on the fs, stats etc). In addition in increases the chances of a state mismatch between the scheduler and webserver (now suddenly the webserver can have newer definitions than the scheduler, who has what?) I do understand the "parsing of complex dags" issue, but I wonder if it is the right way of doing it. 

I would support a combination between #1603 and this. That would solve two issues from the user's perspective and reduce redundant polling and keep possible mismatches between the scheduler and webserver as low as possible.

@bolkedebruin , thanks a lot for your useful comments that definitely helped improving the code quality. If you do not have any other comments, this PR can be considered finished from my side.

Cheers
Looks good to me, thanks

I've missed that error since it doesn't occur in my local environment. Thanks for the comment! I'm not sure its cause for now, but I'll investigate it.
Oracle 11 maximum varchar2 length is 2000.

After some experiments, I've figured out the cause. information_schema.tables is a view in PostgreSQL, and PostgreSQL 9.1 probably doesn't support copying tables by "CREATE TABLE LIKE" from views.
The following sentence appears in [9.2 document](https://www.postgresql.org/docs/9.2/static/sql-createtable.html) for the first time, and not in [9.1](https://www.postgresql.org/docs/9.1/static/sql-createtable.html).

> The LIKE clause can also be used to copy columns from views, foreign tables, or composite types.

Possible solutions are:
1. specifying PostgreSQL version greater than 9.1 in .travis.yml
2. instead of a view, using a real table (such as pg_class, information_schema.sql_languages or something) as a copying source

@criccomini What version of PostgreSQL does Airflow officially support? If 9.1 is not supported, I prefer the first option for consistency with MySQL's test case.


```
from airflow.hooks.base_hook import BaseHook
from airflow.models import BaseOperator


# Will show up under airflow.hooks.PluginHook
class PluginHook(BaseHook):
    pass

# Will show up under airflow.operators.PluginOperator

    pass

# Defining the plugin class
class AirflowTestPlugin(AirflowPlugin):
    name = "test_plugin"
    operators = [PluginOperator]
    flask_blueprints = []
    hooks = [PluginHook]
    executors = []
    admin_views = []

"""
```

cc @aoen @artwr @mistercrunch 

Since this touches some of the guts of Airflow, want to make sure you're aware of this change.
LGTM

LGTM +1
This is awesome! And will also lead to a more stable internal api in the long term.
LGTM

Not sure if similar changes are needed on the javascript side of things? 

Further, the db models use `func.now()`. Looks like `func.now()` is indeed dependent on the DB server - http://stackoverflow.com/questions/13370317/sqlalchemy-default-datetime. How concerned should we be of network latency here? Is it ok to change this to `datetime.utcnow()` for the sake of consistency and system-independent guarantees?

Took another pass and left some comments.

Make sure to take a look at the failing test. Looks like a legit failure after your changes.

Also, we should block on @bolkedebruin for this one, I think, since it's touching DagRun, and he's refactoring stuff there.

any thoughts on the question re: templating?

> Currently for EmrCreateJobFlowOperator job_flow_overrides are a python dictionary that allow DAG specific overrides for the EMR connection config (contained in the extra of an Airlfow Connection). However, this python dictionary doesn't allow for templating (for example if you wanted to name your cluster differently for each execution date). Would it make more sense for it to be json overrides, so they could be templated?
Looks good to me

Found an example of a potential issue without having consistent `utcnow()` instead of `now()`. Here: https://github.com/apache/incubator-airflow/blob/master/airflow/models.py#L918 we are comparing a dags `execution_date` which is set by the scheduler with a tasks `end_date` which is set by the worker. So if the worker and scheduler are running on 2 different timezones, we will be doing a faulty comparison here.

Exponential back-off algos are best implemented as bounded, exponential back-off algos. In this case, the bound is provided by the `retries` configuration parameter on the Task (or default_args dict passed to the DAG and then to the tasks). For reasonable values of retries, the delay can grow pretty quickly to appear interminably high, so it might be a good idea to offer another optional parameter for max_retry_delay.

Jinja templating acts on string only, so we would have to introspect and do type checking within the dict, or try to template json. I am not a fan of the later at all, because I am pretty sure the jinja brackets will make the json invalid.
